member.summary: Returns the type of the connector for which parameters are provided.

member.name: P:Knx.Bus.Common.Configuration.ConnectorParameters.IsSecure
member.summary: Returns true for secure connectors

member.name: P:Knx.Bus.Common.Configuration.ConnectorParameters.Name
member.summary: Returns or sets the name of the interface.

remarks.para: May be null. The name is set by Falcon when enumerating devices. It has no relevance when opening a connection.
Connection string support: May be given as Name=name (the usual connection string rules apply if name contains special characters like quotes or semicolons).

member.name: P:Knx.Bus.Common.Configuration.ConnectorParameters.Exclusive
member.summary: Gets or sets the flag whether the connector should be opened exclusive.

remarks.para:
This means:
Connect exclusive:
The connection request will fail if there exists already a connection with this connector parameters but non-exclusive.
The connection request will fail if there exists already a connection with this connector parameters also exclusive.
The connection request will succeed if there exists no other connection with this connector parameters.
Connect non-exclusive:
The connection request will fail if there exists already a connection with this connector parameters but exclusive.
The connection request will succeed if there exists already a connection with this connector parameters also non-exclusive.
The connection request will succeed if there exists no other connection with this connector parameters.
Default: False (non-exclusive).
Important note: Open tunneling connections is always exclusive means the connections with the same parameters can be opened until no more additional addresses are available.
Connection string support: May be given as Exclusive=True.

member.summary: This class provides parameters used to open a secure KNXnet/IP Device Management connection.

remarks.code: Type=KnxIpcEmiTl;Secure=True;(other parameters like for non-secure device management connections)
remarks.para:
By default, security-sensitive information like keys and password hashes are not included in the connection string.
If security-critical information shall be included in the connection string, it has to be encrypted by a password provided by the Falcon client. Use the and methods in this case.
Remark on serialization
Also when using the .NET serialization, security-sensitive information like keys and password hashes are not serialized.

If security-critical information shall be serialized, a password has to be provided by the Falcon client to encrypt the data via the "additional" parameter of the constructor. The object passed here can be one of the following:
The password itself as object.
An object implementing the interface ; the password will ber retrieved by calling .
An object implementing the interface ; Falcon will then retrieve the interface via GetService(typeof(IProvideSecureSerializationPassword)).

member.name: P:Knx.Bus.Common.Configuration.KnxIpSecureDeviceManagementConnectorParameters.UserId
member.summary: User id for authentication to the server (together with UserPasswordHash).
member.remarks:
0x01: Management level access.
0x02..0x7f: User level access.
0x00 and 0x80..0xff: Reserved.
0x01: Management level access. 0x02..0x7f: User level access. 0x00 and 0x80..0xff: Reserved. Default is 1 (management level access).

member.name: P:Knx.Bus.Common.Configuration.KnxIpSecureDeviceManagementConnectorParameters.UserPasswordHash
member.summary: Password hash for authentication to the server (together with UserId).
member.remarks: The password hash is UserId specific. The default password hash is the hash of the empty string (e9c304b914a35175fd7d1c673ab52fe1). Use to generate the user password hash for a given password.

member.name: P:Knx.Bus.Common.Configuration.KnxIpSecureDeviceManagementConnectorParameters.Password
member.summary: Password for authentication to the server (for ETS use only!).
member.remarks: See UserPasswordHash. Setting this will set the UserPasswordHash. Reading this will return the last set password.

member.name: P:Knx.Bus.Common.Configuration.KnxIpSecureDeviceManagementConnectorParameters.DeviceAuthenticationCodeHash
member.summary: Device authentication code hash.
member.remarks: This is used to optionally check the authenticity of the device. This must be either set to byte[16] or null: byte[16]: DeviceAuthenticationCodeHash is verified against the device authentication code hash sent by the device. An error is caused if they do not match. null: The device authentication code hash sent by the device is ignored. The user ultimately trusts that Falcon is talking to the correct device. Default is null. Use to generate the hash for a password.

member.name: M:Knx.Bus.Common.Configuration.KnxIpSecureDeviceManagementConnectorParameters.GetUserPasswordHash(System.Security.SecureString)

member.remarks: The hash is calculated using this algorithm: PBKDF2(hmac=HMAC-SHA256, password, salt = "user-password.1.secure.ip.knx.org", iterations = 65536, derived_key_length_in_bytes = 16)

Alternatively, if security-critical information shall be included in the connection string, it has to be encrypted by a password provided by the Falcon client. Use the and methods in this case.
Remark on serialization
Also when using the .NET serialization, security-sensitive information like keys and password hashes are not serialized.
If there is an ETS keyring file available, the method can be used to load the security data from there.

Alternatively, if security-critical information shall be serialized, a password has to be provided by the Falcon client to encrypt the data via the "additional" parameter of the constructor. The object passed here can be one of the following:
The password itself as object.
An object implementing the interface ; the password will ber retrieved by calling .

member.name: F:Knx.Bus.Common.Configuration.KnxIpSecureRoutingConnectorParameters._backboneKey
member.summary: Multicast group key, 16 bytes.

member.name: F:Knx.Bus.Common.Configuration.KnxIpSecureRoutingConnectorParameters._latencyToleranceInMs
member.summary: Multicast latency tolerance in ms: Packets which are older than the current group timer are accepted if their age is less than the latency tolerance. Packets which are younger than the current group timer are always accepted, regardless of the age difference. (Such packets update the group timer.)

member.name: F:Knx.Bus.Common.Configuration.KnxIpSecureRoutingConnectorParameters._syncLatencyToleranceInMs
member.summary: Sync latency tolerance in [ms]. Group timers of devices are considered to be in sync (and do not require further synchronization) if their difference is less than this tolerance. The sync latency tolerance is given in ms. It should be set so that the latency of at least 90% of all network traffic is below the sync latency tolerance. This must be significantly less than the LatencyTolerance. The default value is 200 ms which is 10% of the LatencyTolerance.

member.name: T:Knx.Bus.Common.Configuration.KnxIpSecureRoutingConnectorParameters.SecureConnectMode
member.summary: The ConnectMode specifies the behavior of Bus.Connect() regarding synchronizing the multicast group-timer with other devices in the network.

summary.para: Bus.Connect() blocks until either a trusted TIMER_NOTIFY has been received, or until maxDelayResponse+latencyTolerance elapsed.

The effect is that Bus.Connect() will normally block until a time keeper sent a timer notify correction (TIMER_NOTIFY with our sequence number and message tag). If ne time keeper is currently in the network, it will always block for maxDelayResponse+latencyTolerance so that all devices had the opportunity to correct the time. After Bus.Connect() returns it is safe to send or receive SECURE_WRAPPER frames. This is the default ConnectMode and this is the only secure ConnectMode. This mode should always be used unless there are strong reasons to use one of the other modes.
Bus.Connect() blocks until the first TIMER_NOTIFY has been received.

This mode is not secure. This mode assumes that all communication on the network can be trusted which is not the case in real-life scenarios. This mode makes the communication (send+receive) of this instance vulnerable to replay-attacks in the initial phase after startup. This mode should only be used for test setups (where all devices can be inherently trusted) or in situations where the authenticity of SECURE_WRAPPER frames sent or received by this instance in the initial phase after startup is not important to the application. Note that the group-timer is synchronized with the other devices as usual, but Bus.Connect() will return before the initial synchronization completed.
Bus.Connect() returns immediately, without synchronizing the group-timer with any devices on the network.

Without any other precautions all SECURE_WRAPPER frames send by this instance during the initial phase (until the automatic synchronization completed) are likely to be dropped by all other devices on the network. Also all received SECURE_WRAPPER frames received during this initial phase cannot be trusted as they may come from replay-attacks. This mode is insecure unless InitialGroupTimer is set to the current group-timer just before calling Bus.Connect(). An application which knows the current and up-to-date group-timer value can set the InitialGroupTimer property together with this mode. In this case the application guarantees the synchronization and the communication is as reliable as in the ConnectSynchronized mode.
Note that the group-timer is synchronized with the other devices as usual, but Bus.Connect() will return before the initial synchronization completed.

member.name: P:Knx.Bus.Common.Configuration.KnxIpSecureRoutingConnectorParameters.LatencyTolerance
member.summary: Gets or sets the latency tolerance in milliseconds.
member.remarks: Multicast (group) communication which has a higher latency than this tolerance will be discarded. This tolerance should be set to the worst case network latency. The default is 2000 ms.

member.name: P:Knx.Bus.Common.Configuration.KnxIpSecureRoutingConnectorParameters.SyncLatencyTolerance
member.summary: Sync latency tolerance in milliseconds.
member.remarks: Group timers of devices are considered to be in sync (and do not require further synchronization) if their difference is less than this tolerance. The sync latency tolerance is given in ms. It should be set so that the latency of at least 90% of all network traffic is below the sync latency tolerance. This must be significantly less than the LatencyTolerance. The default value is 200 ms which is 10% of the LatencyTolerance.

member.name: P:Knx.Bus.Common.Configuration.KnxIpSecureRoutingConnectorParameters.ConnectMode
member.summary: Set or get the ConnectMode.
member.remarks: This can be used to influence the timing behavior and reliability of Bus.Connect(). The default (ConnectSynchronized) is suitable for all secure applications and should only be overridden in specific situations. See modes in SecureConnectMode.

member.name: P:Knx.Bus.Common.Configuration.KnxIpSecureRoutingConnectorParameters.InitialGroupTimer
member.summary: Set or get the initial group-timer used by this instance when Bus.Connect() is called.
member.remarks:
The default is 0 which is suitable for all secure applications. The semantics differ depending on the ConnectMode:
ConnectMode == ConnectUnsynchronized:
In this mode InitialGroupTimer specifies the group-timer used during the initial phase until the normal automatic synchronization with the other devices on the network completed. If the current group-timer is known (through whatever means) by this instance setting ConnectMode to ConnectUnsynchronized and setting InitialGroupTimer to the current group-timer can be used to implement a fast and still secure Bus.Connect() which does not block. This is the primary use-case of the InitialGroupTimer property.
ConnectMode == ConnectSynchronized or ConnectSynchronizedTrustFirstResponse:
InitialGroupTimer is usually not set for these modes. The InitialGroupTimer value specifies the timestamp sent in the initial TIMER_NOTIFY. If this is lower than the current group-timer value used in the network this value is not relevant (thus it is always fine to use the default of 0).
If this is higher than the current group-timer value used in the network this will increase the current group-timer value used in the network to the specified value immediately (when the initial TIMER_NOTIFY sent by this instance is received by all other instances). This should generally be avoided as it may result in valid in-flight SECURE_WRAPPER frames to be dropped by this instance and/or other devices.
This should only be done in very specific maintenance situations like artificial test scenarios.

member.name: P:Knx.Bus.Common.Configuration.KnxIpSecureTunnelingConnectorParameters.UserId
member.summary: Gets or sets the User id for authentication to the server (together with UserPasswordHash).
member.remarks:
0x01: Management level access.
0x02..0x7f: User level access.
0x00 and 0x80..0xff: Reserved.
Default is 1 (management level access).

member.name: P:Knx.Bus.Common.Configuration.KnxIpSecureTunnelingConnectorParameters.UserPasswordHash
member.summary: Password hash for authentication to the server (together with UserId).
member.remarks: The password hash is UserId specific. The default password hash is the hash of the empty string (e9c304b914a35175fd7d1c673ab52fe1). Use to generate the user password hash for a given password.

member.name: P:Knx.Bus.Common.Configuration.KnxIpSecureTunnelingConnectorParameters.Password
member.summary: Password for authentication to the server (for ETS use only!).
member.remarks: See UserPasswordHash. Setting this will set the UserPasswordHash. Reading this will return the last set password.

member.name: P:Knx.Bus.Common.Configuration.KnxIpSecureTunnelingConnectorParameters.DeviceAuthenticationCodeHash
member.summary: Device authentication code hash.
member.remarks: This is used to optionally check the authenticity of the device. This must be either set to byte[16] or null: byte[16]: DeviceAuthenticationCodeHash is verified against the device authentication code hash sent by the device. An error is caused if they do not match. null: The device authentication code hash sent by the device is ignored. The user ultimately trusts that Falcon is talking to the correct device. Default is null. Use to generate the hash for a password.

member.name: M:Knx.Bus.Common.Configuration.KnxIpSecureTunnelingConnectorParameters.GetUserPasswordHash(System.Security.SecureString)
member.summary: Convert a textual user password into a hash suitable for UserPasswordHash.
member.remarks: The hash is calculated using this algorithm: PBKDF2(hmac=HMAC-SHA256, password, salt = "user-password.1.secure.ip.knx.org", iterations = 65536, derived_key_length_in_bytes = 16)

member.name: M:Knx.Bus.Common.Configuration.KnxIpSecureTunnelingConnectorParameters.GetDeviceAuthenticationCodeHash(System.Security.SecureString)
member.summary: Convert a textual device authentication code password into a hash suitable for DeviceAuthenticationCodeHash.
member.remarks: The hash is calculated using this algorithm: PBKDF2(hmac=HMAC-SHA256, password, salt = "device-authentication-code.1.secure.ip.knx.org", iterations = 65536, derived_key_length_in_bytes = 16)

member.name: F:Knx.Bus.Common.Configuration.KnxIpSecureTunnelingConnectorParameters.DefaultUserPasswordHash
member.summary: Password hash of default user password, the empty password.

member.name: P:Knx.Bus.Common.Configuration.KnxIpTunnelingConnectorParameters.IndividualAddress
member.summary: Get or sets individual address to be requested to be used for tunneling on the field medium (tunneling v2).
member.remarks:
If this is given and the tunneling server does not support tunneling v2, opening the connection will fail. If the tunneling server supports tunneling v2 but the given address is not available:
If the error code from the tunneling server is E_NO_TUNNELING_ADDRESS or E_CONNECTION_IN_USE and is true, the connect is retried accepting any individual address (basic CRI).
Otherwise, opening the connection will fail.

member.name: P:Knx.Bus.Common.Configuration.KnxIpTunnelingConnectorParameters.FallbackToAnyIndividualAddress
member.summary: Determines the behaviour if the connection with the address given in is not available.

member.name: T:Knx.Bus.Common.Configuration.UsbConnectorParameters
member.summary: This class provides parameters used to open an USB connection.
member.remarks:
The parameters are used in the following way to determine which USB connection shall be opened:
If is set, it is first tried to open the USB interface with this USB device path. If this fails, the algorithm continues with the next step.
If is set, the connected USB interface with this individual address is opened. If no or multiple USB interfaces with this individual address are found, opening fails.
If is set, it is used as index into the list of all connected USB interfaces.
Connection string support
Type=USB;DevicePath=usbpath
Type=USB;PreferredAddressToOpen=indaddr
Type=USB;DeviceIndex=number
If the default value of a property shall be used, the corresponding part of the connection string can be omitted.

member.name: T:Knx.Bus.Common.Curve25519
member.summary:
Curve25519 implementation.
- C# port of C module curve25519-donna.c https://code.google.com/p/curve25519-donna/ by Adam Langley <agl@imperialviolet.org>
- Curve25519 webpage: http://cr.yp.to/ecdh.html
- Curve25519 paper from D. J. Bernstein: [curve25519] 22pp. (PDF) D. J. Bernstein. Curve25519: new Diffie-Hellman speed records. Proceedings of PKC 2006, to appear. Document ID: 4230efdfa673480fc079449d90f322c0. URL: http://cr.yp.to/papers.html#curve25519. Date: 2006.02.09. Supersedes: (PDF) 2005.11.15.

member.name: T:Knx.Bus.Common.DataSecurity.DeviceCommunicationSecurity
member.summary: Provides the necessary information for secure point-to-point communication.
member.remarks: An instance of this class can either be created programmatically using the class, or by loading security data exported from ETS.

member.name: M:Knx.Bus.Common.DataSecurity.DeviceCommunicationSecurity.Load(System.String,System.Security.SecureString,Knx.Bus.Common.IndividualAddress)
member.summary: Load point-to-point keys from a keyring file (*.knxkeys) exported from ETS.
member.param: The individual address of the interface to use
member.remarks: ETS 5.6 currently does not support configuring P2P keys and thus the knxkeys file exported by ETS 5.6 will not contain any P2P keys.

member.name: M:Knx.Bus.Common.DataSecurity.DeviceCommunicationSecurity.Load(System.IO.Stream,System.Security.SecureString,Knx.Bus.Common.IndividualAddress)
member.summary: Load point-to-point keys from a keyring file (*.knxkeys) exported from ETS.
member.param: The data from the knxkeys file
The individual address of the interface to use
member.remarks: ETS 5.6 currently does not support configuring P2P keys and thus the knxkeys file exported by ETS 5.6 will not contain any P2P keys.

member.name: M:Knx.Bus.Common.DataSecurity.DeviceCommunicationSecurity.Load(System.IO.Stream,System.Security.SecureString,Knx.Bus.Common.IndividualAddress,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Load point-to-point keys from a keyring file (*.knxkeys) exported from ETS.
member.param: The data from the knxkeys file
The individual address of the interface to use
If true, the file signature is not validated. Use this only for test purposes because a manipulated knxkeys file may present a security risk.
member.remarks: ETS 5.6 currently does not support configuring P2P keys and thus the knxkeys file exported by ETS 5.6 will not contain any P2P keys.

member.summary: Load tool keys from a keyring file (*.knxkeys) exported from ETS.

member.param: The data from the knxkeys file

member.summary: Load tool keys from a keyring file (*.knxkeys) exported from ETS.
member.param: The data from the knxkeys file
If true, the file signature is not validated. Use this only for test purposes because a manipulated knxkeys file may present a security risk.

member.name: M:Knx.Bus.Common.DataSecurity.DeviceCommunicationSecurity.Load(System.IO.Stream,System.Security.SecureString,System.Boolean,System.Boolean,Knx.Bus.Common.IndividualAddress)
member.summary: Load security data from a keyring file (*.knxkeys) exported from ETS.
member.param: The data from the knxkeys file
If true, the file signature is not validated. Use this only for test purposes because a manipulated knxkeys file may present a security risk.
If true, the tool keys are loaded.
If is false, the interface for which the P2P keys should be loaded.

member.name: M:Knx.Bus.Common.DataSecurity.DeviceCommunicationSecurity.LoadDeviceSequenceCounters(System.IO.Stream,System.Security.SecureString)
member.summary: Load the last valid sequence counters of secure devices from an XML stream
member.param: An XML stream containing the sequence counters
Password for validating the signature of the data. If null, no validation is performed; use this only for test purposes because manipulated sequence counters may lead to a denial of service.
member.remarks: See also .

member.name: M:Knx.Bus.Common.DataSecurity.DeviceCommunicationSecurity.SaveDeviceSequenceCounters(System.IO.Stream,System.Security.SecureString)
member.summary: Save the last valid sequence counters of secure devices to an XML stream
member.param: An XML stream containing the sequence counters
Password for creating a signature of the data. If null, no signature is created; use this only for test purposes because manipulated sequence counters may lead to a denial of service.
member.remarks: To prevent replay attacks it is important that the last valid sequence numbers of all communication partners are kept up-to date and persisted across runs. The former is handled automatically by Falcon's Bus object. For the latter, it is advised to call the SaveDeviceSequenceCounters method regularly to save the current sequence counters to a file.

member.name: M:Knx.Bus.Common.DataSecurity.DeviceCommunicationSecurity.LoadDeviceSequenceCounters(System.String,System.Security.SecureString)
member.summary: Load the last valid sequence counters of secure devices from an XML file
member.param: An XML file name containing the sequence counters
Password for validating the signature of the data. If null, no validation is performed; use this only for test purposes because manipulated sequence counters may lead to a denial of service.
member.remarks: See also .

member.name: M:Knx.Bus.Common.DataSecurity.DeviceCommunicationSecurity.SaveDeviceSequenceCounters(System.String,System.Security.SecureString)
member.summary: Save the last valid sequence counters of secure devices to an XML file
member.param: An XML file containing the sequence counters
Password for creating a signature of the data. If null, no signature is created; use this only for test purposes because manipulated sequence counters may lead to a denial of service.

remarks.para: To prevent replay attacks it is important that the last valid sequence numbers of all communication partners are kept up-to date and persisted across runs. The former is handled automatically by Falcon's Bus object. For the latter, it is advised to call the SaveDeviceSequenceCounters method regularly to save the current sequence counters to a file.
This method will temporarily create another file in the same directory named fileName + ".tmp" to ensure atomicity of the write operation. Any existing file with this name will be overwritten.
Of course, must be on a writable volume/directory.

member.name: M:Knx.Bus.Common.GroupAddress.ToString(System.String,System.IFormatProvider)
member.summary: Converts the group address value to its equivalent string representation using the specified format string.
member.param: The format string to be used for formatting the group address value. See remarks section for valid format strings.
The format provider is not supported and can be null.
member.returns: Returns the group address value converted to its equivalent string representation.

remarks.b: This method is used by by using formatting instructions e.g. "{0:G3}" The following format strings are valid:

list.item: "G3": a three level group address string is created in the form '<main>/<middle>/<sub>'
"G2": a two level group address string is created in the form '<main>/<sub>'
"G1": a free group address string is created in its numeric representation.
"X": a free group address string is created in its hexadecimal representation using upper-case letters. The returned string is always filled up with leading zeros.
"x": a free group address string is created in its hexadecimal representation using lower-case letters. The returned string is always filled up with leading zeros.
null: a free group address string is created in its numeric representation. This is the default behaviour.

member.name: M:Knx.Bus.Common.GroupAddress.ToString(System.String)
member.summary: Converts the group address value to its equivalent string representation using the specified format string.
member.param: The format string to be used for formatting the group address value. See remarks section for valid format strings.
member.returns: Returns the group address value converted to its equivalent string representation.

remarks.b: The following format strings are valid:

list.item: "G3": a three level group address string is created in the form '<main>/<middle>/<sub>'
"G2": a two level group address string is created in the form '<main>/<sub>'
"G1": a free group address string is created in its numeric representation.
"X": a free group address string is created in its hexadecimal representation using upper-case letters. The returned string is always filled up with leading zeros.
"x": a free group address string is created in its hexadecimal representation using lower-case letters. The returned string is always filled up with leading zeros.
null: a free group address string is created in its numeric representation. This is the default behaviour.

member.name: M:Knx.Bus.Common.GroupValues.GroupValue.Parse(System.String)
member.summary: Parse the specified group value into a GroupValue object.
member.remarks:
can be in one of the following formats:
InputResultExamples
"true"/"false" (case-insensitive)1 bit group value"false" "true"
Integer between 0 and 32 bit group value as "2" "0x2"
Integer between 4 and 154 bit group value as "8" "$8"
Integer between 16 and 636 bit group value as "40" "0x28"
Integer between 64 and 2558 bit group value"120" "$78"
At least two hexadecimal bytes"0x02 0x04"
Hexadecimal values are denoted by a leading "0x" or "$".

member.name: T:Knx.Bus.Common.ICustomBusDriver
member.summary: Interface to be implemented by user-provided communication drivers.

remarks.para: A user-provided communication driver is foreseen exclusively for situations where Falcon is used in an embedded device with specialized communication hardware not accessible by the built in USB or IP communication options (e.g. a TP/UART).

list.item: After successful construction, Falcon calls the method exactly once. Only if the Open call succeeds, other methods and properties of this interface are accessed.
When finished with the driver, Falcon calls the method as last method of this interface.
If the object in addition implements , is called. This is done even if the Open call failed.

remarks.para:
Threading:
Except for the and calls which are never performed in parallel with other calls, the properties and methods may be called by Falcon on any thread at any time, also in parallel. The object implementing this interface must therefore implement any required locking itself. The two callback methods passed in the call may be called on any thread. Falcon guarantees that these callback will never block.

member.name: P:Knx.Bus.Common.ICustomBusDriver.LocalMediumType

member.remarks: This information is used by Falcon e.g. to choose one of several possible implementation of network management procedures.

member.summary: Get the maximum possible APDU length
member.remarks: This information is used by Falcon to restrict the length of sent and received telegrams.

member.name: P:Knx.Bus.Common.ICustomBusDriver.State
member.summary: Get the state of the connection
member.returns: true if the connection is available, false if the driver detects a problem with the communication hardware or if the connection to the KNX medium is broken.

member.summary: Get or set the individual address of the interface
member.exception: If setting the individual address fails

member.summary: Get or set the domain address of the interface (if the medium supports it)
member.exception: If setting the domain address fails

member.name: M:Knx.Bus.Common.ICustomBusDriver.Open(Knx.Bus.Common.ConnectorMode,System.String,System.Action{System.Byte[]},System.Action{System.Boolean})
member.summary: Called by Falcon to open the driver
member.param: Whenever a message from the bus is received by the driver, inform Falcon about it via this callback, passing the message as cEMI frame.
Whenever the connection state () changes, inform Falcon about it via this callback, passing the new state as parameter
member.exception: If opening the connection fails.

member.name: M:Knx.Bus.Common.ICustomBusDriver.Close
member.summary: Called by Falcon to close the driver
member.remarks: After this call, the driver must not call the callbacks passed in the method any more.

member.name: M:Knx.Bus.Common.ICustomBusDriver.Send(System.Byte[])
member.summary: Called by Falcon to initiate sending a message to the bus
member.param: The message to be sent as cEMI frame; usually a L_Data.req
member.exception: If sending the message fails.
member.remarks: The call should return as soon as the message was successfully queued for sending. The link layer confirmation (negative or positive) has to be reported by passing the L_Data.conf to the received callback as soon as it is available.

member.name: M:Knx.Bus.Common.SecureCryptoEngineAes128.DataSecurityEncryptCcm(System.Byte[],System.Byte[],Knx.Bus.Common.Telegrams.SecureTelegram,System.Byte[]@)
member.summary: Encrypt and calculate MAC make using CCM, in the context of DataSecurity.
member.param: Data which is only to be authenticated. May be null.

member.summary: Decrypt pData and MAC in the context of DataSecurity.
member.param: Encrypted data which should be decrypted. This must not contain a MAC.
SecureTelegram which is used to build Ctr_0. The fields SeqNr, Sa and DA are used.
Out: Decrypted MAC (4 bytes) or null if encryptedMac was null.

member.summary: Calculate plain MAC from plain aData and pData in the context of data security.
member.param: Plain data which will be or was encrypted.
Context to build B_0 and Ctr_0.

member.name: M:Knx.Bus.Common.SecureCryptoEngineAes128.IpSecurityCalcUnencryptedCcmMac(System.Byte[],System.Byte[],System.UInt64,System.UInt64,System.UInt16)
member.summary: Calc unencrypted CBC-MAC of KNX-CCM according to AN158 and AN159 in the context of IpSecurity.
member.param: Data which is authenticated but which will not be encrypted later.
Data which is authenticated and which will be encrypted later. May be null.
Sequence number which goes into the top 6 bytes of the nonce.
member.returns: 16 byte CBC-MAC of a_bytes and p_bytes

member.name: M:Knx.Bus.Common.SecureCryptoEngineAes128.CcmCalcCbcMacInternal(System.Byte[],System.Byte[],System.Byte[],System.Boolean)
member.summary: Calc CBC-MAC according to RFC 3610. This is verified against the RFC 3610 test vectors in SecureCryptoEngineTest.
member.param: Data which is authenticated but which will not be encrypted later. May be null.
Data which is authenticated and which will be encrypted later. May be null.
Block b_0 for the CBC-MAC algorithm. According to RFC 3610 it contains flags, nonce and the length of p_bytes. For KNX it just contains the nonce and the length of p_bytes. See BuildB0().

Set this to false to not insert null bytes after A to align to a 16 byte boundary, which is a KNX specific optimization. Set this to true to get the original CCM behavior (used to check against RFC3610 reference vectors).
member.returns: 16 byte CBC-MAC of a_bytes and p_bytes

member.name: M:Knx.Bus.Common.SecureCryptoEngineAes128.IpSecurityEncryptCcm(System.Byte[],System.Byte[],System.UInt64,System.UInt64,System.UInt16)
member.summary: Encrypt p_bytes using KNX-CCM according to AN158 and AN159 in the context of IpSecurity.
member.param: Plain text data which is to be encrypted.
CBC-MAC of a_bytes and p_bytes from CcmCalcCbcMac().
member.returns: Encrypted data containing p_bytes and mac_bytes in an encrypted form.

member.name: M:Knx.Bus.Common.SecureCryptoEngineAes128.CcmEncryptInternal(System.Byte[],System.Byte[],System.Byte[],System.Int32)
member.summary: Encrypt p_bytes and mac_bytes according to RFC 3610. This is verified against the RFC 3610 test vectors, see Test().
member.param: Plain text data which is to be encrypted. May be null in case no plain text data is to be encrypted (then just the MAC is encrypted).
CBC-MAC of a_bytes and p_bytes from CcmCalcCbcMac[Internal]().
Ctr_0 value for the CTR encryption mode.

Number of bytes of S0 used for encrypting the MAC. Offset of the cipherpad bytes used for p_bytes in the cipherpad. 16 bytes in the context of KNX/IP and in the context of CCM (RFC3610). 4 Bytes for KNX DataSecurity. Must be >= mac_bytes.Length.
member.returns: Encrypted data containing p_bytes and mac_bytes in an encrypted form.

member.name: M:Knx.Bus.Common.SecureCryptoEngineAes128.IpSecurityDecryptCcm(System.Byte[],System.UInt64,System.UInt64,System.UInt16)
member.summary: Decrypt p_bytes and mac_bytes according to AN158 and AN159.
member.param: Encrypted data containing p_bytes and mac_bytes. The last 16 bytes are encrypted mac_bytes. Must be at least 16 bytes long.
member.returns: Decrypted p_bytes + mac_bytes. The last 16 bytes are mac_bytes.

member.name: M:Knx.Bus.Common.SecureCryptoEngineAes128.CcmDecryptInternal(System.Byte[],System.Byte[],System.Byte[],System.Byte[]@,System.Int32)
member.summary: Decrypt p_bytes and mac_bytes according to AN158 and AN159.
member.param: Encrypted data (P) without MAC. May be null.
Encrypted MAC. May be 0..16 bytes or null.
Decrypted MAC is returned in this reference, or null if cipherMac is null.

Number of bytes of S0 used for decrypting the MAC. Offset of the cipherpad bytes used for p_bytes in the cipherpad. 16 bytes in the context of KNX/IP and in the context of CCM (RFC3610). 4 Bytes for KNX DataSecurity. Must be >= cipherMac.Length.
member.returns: plainData as return value and plainMac in plainMac

member.name: M:Knx.Bus.Common.SecureCryptoEngineAes128.GenerateCipherPad(System.Int32,System.Byte[])
member.summary: Generate cipher-pad for CCM encryption. This is called S (S_0, S_1 ...) in RFC 3610. Data is encrypted by XORing it with this cipher-pad. Note: S_0 is returned in the first 16 bytes and is usually later used to encrypt the CBC-MAC which is then stored in the _last_ 16 bytes of the encrypted output.

member.summary: Build B_0 for CBC-MAC according to KNX AN159 (NOT according to RFC 3610) in the context of IpSecurity.

member.name: P:Knx.Bus.Common.Telegrams.BusmonitorTelegram.Telegrams
member.summary: Gets the enclosed telegram(s).

remarks.para:
The telegrams may be of the following types:
null if the data cannot be interpreted
with =true if the data represents an TP1 immediate ACK
A subtype of if the data is a valid frame
Note: BiBat may put multiple KNX messages in one RF block. This is currently not supported by Falcon.
